Key Findings

  • Chi-squared value of 2,338: Rossendale's payment amounts show a statistically significant deviation from Benford's Law (p < 0.001)
  • Digit 2 is over-represented: The leading digit 2 appears 6.3% more often than expected — the largest deviation
  • Large sample inflates the statistic: With 27,784 transactions, even minor deviations produce extreme chi-squared values
  • Not proof of fraud: Benford's Law is a screening tool, not a verdict — many legitimate factors cause deviations

What Is Benford's Law?

Benford's Law is a mathematical observation that in many naturally occurring datasets, the leading digit is not equally distributed. The digit 1 appears as the first digit about 30.1% of the time, while 9 appears only 4.6% of the time. This counterintuitive pattern holds for tax returns, population figures, river lengths, and — critically — financial transaction data.

Forensic accountants use Benford's Law as a screening tool for financial fraud. When a dataset deviates significantly from the expected distribution, it warrants further investigation. The technique has been used successfully in detecting corporate fraud, tax evasion, and election irregularities.

Rossendale's Results

Across 27,784 transactions, Rossendale's spending data produces a chi-squared value of 2,337.98 — far above the threshold of 20.09 that indicates statistical significance at the 99.9% confidence level.

The largest deviation is in the digit 2, which appears 6.3% more often than Benford's Law predicts. This means payments starting with 2 (e.g., £200, £2,500, £25,000) are unusually common.

Why Context Matters

Before interpreting this as evidence of manipulation, several important caveats apply:

1. Sample Size Sensitivity

Chi-squared tests become increasingly sensitive with larger samples. With 27,784 transactions, even a deviation that would be unremarkable in a dataset of 500 becomes statistically significant. The 6.3% maximum digit deviation is actually a more practical measure — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

2. Payment Thresholds

Council spending data is typically published above a threshold (£500 for Rossendale). This artificial floor removes transactions starting with digits 1-4 in the hundreds, distorting the expected distribution. If many genuine payments fall between £100 and £499, the remaining data will naturally deviate from Benford's Law.

3. Standardised Amounts

Council payments often follow standard scales — salary bands, grant amounts, licence fees — that cluster around specific values rather than following natural variation. A council that pays 50 employees the same monthly salary will show 50 identical amounts, skewing the digit distribution.

4. Round Numbers

Rossendale has 673 exact round-number payments over £5,000, totalling £8.1 million. These may represent budget allocations, grant payments, or estimates rather than precise invoiced amounts, and they disproportionately affect the leading digit distribution.

What You Can Do

  • Explore the DOGE page: The AI DOGE Investigation page explains all statistical findings with full context
  • Learn more: Search for "Benford's Law" on Wikipedia for an accessible introduction to the mathematics
  • Check other councils: Compare Rossendale's Benford's deviation to Burnley, Hyndburn, and Pendle — most show similar patterns
